item.description: A little bit of a clean-up on the blade, and a first attempt at the dreaded eye lenses. At the most, absolute maximum, only 80% cross-eyed?

It has been weeks since I did any actual painting. I’m really not sure this effect on the pointy bitâ€™s working, or even in keeping with the rest of the model, but it is ultimately more acrylic-on-plastic so I’m calling it a win!
Starting to add some secondary colours now that Tyrion-paralysis has ended.
Sketching in the light placement for Fancy Ladâ€™s eventual Fancy Backside. Very rough sketch. (Please only squint while viewing ðŸ˜…)
Fancy Trousers time.
And heâ€™ll need those mittens, itâ€™s cold in space.

Head, shoulder, knee and toes (knee and toes). It may be a royal pain trying to colour-match freehand mistakes on a stippled shoulder gradient, but here we are. Itâ€™s all just a mix of the same two paints. How bad could it get ðŸ˜¬

Random midweek experiments: I wondered if I’d be able to get a smooth blend from quite dark to quite bright going brown-to-ivories, without resorting to an airbrush. I think the answer is definitely ’no’, at least with this approach. It gives its own effect though, the scratchiness of it could probably be read as weathering? I’ll have to give stippling a try.
I appear to be locked into an Accidental Grimdark with this one.
What do we reckon here, HobbyPals? Is the freehanding actually accomplishing anything, or just distracting from the initial pleasant simplicity?
Another incredibly quick â€˜two-toneâ€™ test.
/taps temple: canâ€™t be a bog standard ork checkerboard if itâ€™s tilted into diamonds, thatâ€™s clearly elf territoryâ€¦
Itâ€™s not the tidiest highlighting job in the world, but Iâ€™m slightly irritated that this very quick two-tone â€˜testerâ€™ model is already looking nicer than the stuff I spend weeks onâ€¦
Right, enough procrastination, operation Fix The Bad Shadow begins.

I added an attempt at a cast shadow on the base, trying to emphasise that I want the scene to read as though lit from a shaft of light above, but I hated it so much that I set it aside for a full week ðŸ˜… I think itâ€™s just far too extreme, Iâ€™ll try to soften it and lighten it to recover.
His little boots have a strap around them that I wasnâ€™t expecting. Sudden colour paralysis.

I have, definitely intentionally, decided that he should have Very Shiny arms. Didnâ€™t come up much in the show, but a big part of the books.

(Awkward Look Monkey Puppet dot gif)
Starting into his jerkin and only realising while taking this photo that the filigree is approximately the same width as the ridges of my fingerprints ðŸ˜¬
I mean I canâ€™t leave him without hairâ€¦
Wellâ€¦ I know what Iâ€™ll be working on when I get the Farseer finished up. Canâ€™t believe itâ€™s even smaller. Look at that likeness though, even just primed!
When I say â€˜finish the Farseerâ€™ first, I obviously donâ€™t mean not putting any paint on that tiny little face.
Blend, blend, blendâ€”checks to confirm that almost nothing has changedâ€”blend, blend, blend. What even is white?

This stretch could be a long one: the Actual White bits.

Adding blue-gray over the vibrant white primer and a lesser white to the brightest white to try to make blue-gray and lesser white look like a more vibrant white (at scale). As you do.

Deep in the ugly, patchy phase of it at the moment.
Starting on gloves and bangles. Critical aspects of any wargaming mini.

Filling in the remaining white space on the torso. Itâ€™s only when you take the photo that you realise thereâ€™s a fair bit more imprecision than you saw with your Human Eyeball. Fair play to the YouTubers out there getting crispy lines while filming what theyâ€™re up to.
Expanding the red, waiting for the storm.

I canâ€™t remember who originally shared the tip, but if you struggle (like me) to get your non-metallics to actually look â€˜shinyâ€™, you can take a photo of your initial light placement on the mini and just boost the contrast to max and brightness to min. Try to match what you see with paint.
Slowly now pushing the painted contrast to better match the boosted version, trying to make the chest ornamentation seem like a distinct material from the fabric.
Never painted an elf before, space or otherwise, despite falling in love with Jes Goodwinâ€™s art back in the day. But this little sculpt is gorgeous.
The order in which I choose to apply paint is both baffling and entirely self-inflicted.
Of course, gentle reader, he would start into some non-metallic nonsense before he even has the base colours down. The boyâ€™s a fool.

Iâ€™m determined that 2025 is the year I actually finish painting a thing. Anything. Just one will do. Iâ€™m nominating this lil guy. Still a long way to go, but Iâ€™ve stopped myself giving up in disgust and re-priming him three separate times now, so thatâ€™s progress!

Definitely time to start some regular creative stuff again and hope to carry hobby-momentum through into the new year.

Not the greatest start to day one though, I’m going to have to learn how to putty re-sculpt a resin-related-injury on the fuzzy fella.
Trying to mimic some of the light placement on the bracer referencing Sergioâ€™s timelapse video. Still using quite a large brush at this point due to the Unaccustomed Vastness of space.
Even just roughly blocking in the base colours is going to take the rest of my natural lifeâ€¦
There’s something profane in tarnishing a pristine blank canvas.
Slowly increasing purpleation and general red enyellowment.
Hmm. Not sure if this reads as cast-shadow or just brush-slipâ€¦

Not only did the arm snap off, I hadnâ€™t noticed that the face didnâ€™t even print correctly until I reached it, so a quick segue into something else entirely. Letâ€™s keep the purple theme and see if I can ultimately get this to read as metallic.
Kinda like these reds too.
From one meme to another, definitely not painting Skeletor for an attempt at this month’s Fedipaint.

Huh, turns out Iâ€™m genuinely not painting Skeletor. I remember him as purple with yellow accents, when he is, of course, blue with purple. Is it possible I just have a weird obsession with yellow boots now?

Well thatâ€™s less than ideal. Just starting on the non-metallics and he tried to run away. Now showing one of the real downsides of resin prints - on contact with soft carpet from maybe a one metre drop, â€˜his armâ€™s offâ€™. Half tempted to bodge an oversize Ork power claw on there.
The absurdity continues.
A braver painter would just straight up Bombadil this guy.

Eldest.

â€¦ ?
Itâ€™s basically Orktober, right? The season arrives earlier and earlierâ€¦
I realise ‘unnecessary frilly bib’ may not immediately scream grimdark, but it definitely feels like a Blanche-ism…
Annoyingly, the thing I like most in this WIP shot is the texture palette ðŸ˜…
Just the zenithal prime in place here before I intended to start a base coat of contrast red, but this looks so good Iâ€™m tempted to go for an old-school pre-â€˜bone shadedâ€™ Deathwing experiment.
Slowly trying to add some colour and texture differentiation. I want to push towards a dirty, patinaed gold for the metal.
Currently trying to grok non-metallic metal. Baffled by how well it seems to be going.

“His eyes seemed to root back under all the bulk of that forehead, too thick, too jammy, all full of resistive meats and fluids; exhausting to cut into sections, should such a thing come up.”

I think I may have the turkey sweats.
